answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/case-retina5-q1a.png)

**The answer is (D) All of the above**

The abnormalities on the OCT are:

1. Intra-retinal Cysts (blue arrows)
2. Detached Neurosensory Retina with accumulation of sub-retinal fluid (red star)
3. Vitreous inflammation (yellow hexagon)

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text:
What abnormalities do you visualize in the patient's OCT image?

![](/content/media/case-retina5-q1.png)

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/case-retina5-q1.png)

**The Diagnosis is Macula-Off Retinal Detachment**

There is a complete separation of the neurosensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium. Of note, there are peri-foveal cyst-like spaces between the inner and outer retina that could represent intra-retinal fluid or pre-existing schisis given the patient's high myopia.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text:
An OCT was also performed on the contralateral right eye demonstrating the following:

![](/content/media/case-retina5-q3.png)

What is the diagnosis?

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/case-retina5-q3.png)

**The answer is (C) Retinal Detachment**

This is a macula-threatening retinal detachment. Towards the left side of the OCT scan, sub-retinal fluid can be seen advancing towards the fovea. The foveal contour is preserved with no sub-retinal fluid seen underneath the fovea.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text:
![](/content/media/case-retina5-q4.png)

What layer of the retina is the yellow arrow pointing to?

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/case-retina5-q4.png)

**The answer is (D) Retinal Pigment Epithelium**

The retina is separated from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium, which is the hyper-reflective layer of the retina identified by the yellow arrow. 

Given that this is a macula-on retinal detachment, immediate intervention is warranted to ensure that the detachment does not involve the macula.

title: Case 5
description: 11M presenting with decreased vision and miotic pupil OS
patientPresentation: A 11-year-old aphakic male with a history of microspherophakia s/p cataract surgery presents to an emergency room with decreased vision in the left eye x 3 months. BCVA was 20/40 OD and 20/100 OS. His pupils remained meiotic despite multiple attempts to dilate his pupils pharmacologically. The view to the fundus was poor. An OCT macula was performed demonstrating the following:
footer:
### Learning Objectives

1. Diagnose a retinal detachment on OCT and identify the difference between a macula on and off retinal detachment.
2. Recognize that OCT can be useful in cases where there is a sub-optimal view of the macula.
